conversation.message:
Hi Parent_A—happy to share more, and I’m glad to hear you’re still interested.

1) Supporting transitions/separation (first weeks)
• We plan for a gradual, predictable start: consistent arrival routine, the same teacher greeting, and a clear handoff ritual (e.g., hug + “see you after snack,” then parent leaves promptly).
• We use a “primary point adult” approach early on so your child has a reliable go-to teacher for comfort.
• We normalize feelings and coach coping skills (simple choices, comfort object if helpful, calm corner, short regulating activities).
• We’ll coordinate with you on what works best—some children do best with a short initial day or a brief phased schedule, if feasible.
• We communicate closely in the first 1–2 weeks (quick updates at pick-up and/or a short message) so you know how the day went beyond the initial goodbye.

2) Best ways families partner with teachers
• Share key context early (sleep changes, big transitions at home, sensitivities, what helps your child reset).
• Keep routines consistent (arrival/pick-up, comfort items, sleep schedule when possible).
• Use proactive communication—flag small concerns early so we can problem-solve together.
• Reinforce the same independence skills at home (putting on shoes, tidying up, using words to ask for help).
• Join conferences/goal-setting check-ins so we’re aligned on social-emotional and learning goals.

Timeline, offers, and waitlist
• We’re actively speaking with families now and encourage families who feel we’re a strong fit to submit an application as soon as they’re ready.
• Once we receive an application, we review it quickly and may move to an offer on a rolling basis while the seat is available.
• If the spot fills, we maintain a waitlist and will reach out immediately if a place opens; we also keep waitlisted families updated as timing becomes clearer.

If you’re open to sharing, it would help us understand fit and timing: what start date and schedule are you hoping for (full-time/part-time), and what does a “successful first month” look like for your child (e.g., separation, friendships, routines)?

conversation.message:
Hello Parent_A—thank you for reaching out. I’m glad to share more, and if Nursery_E could be a serious option for you, we can move quickly once we confirm schedule and fit.

**What we prioritize most when reviewing families**
1) **Schedule fit & reliability:** consistency with drop-off/pick-up and the days/hours you need (this is often the biggest driver with staffing ratios).
2) **Family–school partnership:** warm, responsive communication and alignment on supporting children’s independence, kindness, and routines.
3) **Child/program fit:** temperament, any allergies/medical needs, and what environments your child thrives in (structured routines, outdoor time, quieter spaces, etc.).
4) **Prior connections:** we’re happy to note them, but they’re not required; they don’t outweigh schedule/fit.

**Timeline / offers / waitlist**
We review **on a rolling basis**. With **one remaining spot**, we may make an offer as soon as we have enough information to confirm a strong match. If we’re aligned but timing is tight, we may keep a short waitlist, but we generally don’t “hold” a place without an application and clear schedule details.

**Is there an advantage to applying early?**
Yes—because we’re rolling and have limited capacity, **an earlier application keeps you in active consideration while the spot is still available**. Waiting can mean the place is no longer open by the time we review.

If you’re open to it, I’d encourage you to **apply now** so we can evaluate promptly. To confirm fit quickly, could you share:
- Desired start date
- Full-time or part-time (which days)
- Typical drop-off/pick-up times
- Anything your child especially benefits from (routine, outdoor play, smaller groups, sensory supports)

Happy to answer any other questions you’re comparing across programs.
